<Link id="l00064" /><CodeLine lineNumber="64"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00065" /><CodeLine lineNumber="65"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// The RecurrenceDescriptor is used to identify recurrences variables in a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00066" /><CodeLine lineNumber="66"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// loop. Reduction is a special case of recurrence that has uses of the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00067" /><CodeLine lineNumber="67"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// recurrence variable outside the loop. The method isReductionPHI identifies</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00068" /><CodeLine lineNumber="68"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// reductions that are basic recurrences.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00069" /><CodeLine lineNumber="69"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00070" /><CodeLine lineNumber="70"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// Basic recurrences are defined as the summation, product, OR, AND, XOR, min,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00071" /><CodeLine lineNumber="71"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// or max of a set of terms. For example: for(i=0; i&lt;n; i++) &#123; total +=</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00072" /><CodeLine lineNumber="72"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// array&#91;i&#93;; &#125; is a summation of array elements. Basic recurrences are a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00073" /><CodeLine lineNumber="73"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// special case of chains of recurrences (CR). See ScalarEvolution for CR</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00074" /><CodeLine lineNumber="74"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// references.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00075" /><CodeLine lineNumber="75"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00076" /><CodeLine lineNumber="76"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// This struct holds information about recurrence variables.</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00198" /><CodeLine lineNumber="198"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// Returns true if Phi is a fixed-order recurrence. A fixed-order recurrence</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00199" /><CodeLine lineNumber="199"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// is a non-reduction recurrence relation in which the value of the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00200" /><CodeLine lineNumber="200"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// recurrence in the current loop iteration equals a value defined in a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00201" /><CodeLine lineNumber="201"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// previous iteration (e.g. if the value is defined in the previous</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00202" /><CodeLine lineNumber="202"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// iteration, we refer to it as first-order recurrence, if it is defined in</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00203" /><CodeLine lineNumber="203"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// the iteration before the previous, we refer to it as second-order</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00204" /><CodeLine lineNumber="204"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// recurrence and so on). Note that this function optimistically assumes that</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00205" /><CodeLine lineNumber="205"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// uses of the recurrence can be re-ordered if necessary and users need to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00206" /><CodeLine lineNumber="206"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// check and perform the re-ordering.</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00354" /><CodeLine lineNumber="354"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">  /// Returns true if \\p Phi is an induction in the loop \\p L. If \\p Phi is an</span></CodeLine>
